text: Resolution 1820 (2008)
Adopted by the Security Council at its 5916th meeting, on 19 June 2008
The Security Council,

Reaffirming its commitment to the continuing and full implementation of resolution 1325 (2000), 1612 (2005) and 1674 (2006) and recalling the Statements of its president of 31 October 2001 (Security Council/PRST/2001/31), 31 October 2002 (Security Council/PRST/2002/32), 28 October 2004 (Security Council/PRST/2004/40), 27 October 2005 (Security Council/PRST/2005/52), 8 November 2006 (Security Council/PRST/2006/42), 7 March 2007 (Security Council/PRST/2007/5), and 24 October 2007 (Security Council/PRST/2007/40);
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* its commitment to the continuing and full implementation of resolution 1325 (2000), 1612 (2005) and 1674 (2006) and *recalling* the Statements of its president of 31 October 2001 ({{Security Council}}/PRST/2001/31), 31 October 2002 ({{Security Council}}/PRST/2002/32), 28 October 2004 ({{Security Council}}/PRST/2004/40), 27 October 2005 ({{Security Council}}/PRST/2005/52), 8 November 2006 ({{Security Council}}/PRST/2006/42), 7 March 2007 ({{Security Council}}/PRST/2007/5), and 24 October 2007 ({{Security Council}}/PRST/2007/40);
uncertainties: Treated 'Security Council' within document codes (e.g., Security Council/PRST/...) as a mentioned entity. No assignees or deliverables are present as this is a preambular (reinforcing) paragraph.

text: Guided by the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations,
textWithHighlights: Guided by the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations,
uncertainties: Preambular clause using 'Guided by' is not among the specified operative verbs; treated as no operative verb, no assignees or deliverables.

text: Reaffirming also the resolve expressed in the 2005 World Summit Outcome Document to eliminate all forms of violence against women and girls, including by ending impunity and by ensuring the protection of civilians, in particular women and girls, during and after armed conflicts, in accordance with the obligations States have undertaken under international humanitarian law and international human rights law;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming also* the resolve expressed in the 2005 World Summit Outcome Document to eliminate all forms of violence against women and girls, including by ending impunity and by ensuring the protection of civilians, in particular women and girls, during and after armed conflicts, in accordance with the obligations {{States}} have undertaken under international humanitarian law and international human rights law;

text: Recalling the commitments of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action (A/52/231) as well as those contained in the outcome document of the twenty-third Special Session of the United Nations General Assembly entitled “Women 2000: Gender Equality, Development and Peace for the Twenty-first Century” (A/S-23/10/Rev.1), in particular those concerning sexual violence and women in situations of armed conflict;
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* the commitments of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action (A/52/231) as well as those contained in the outcome document of the twenty-third Special Session of the {{United Nations General Assembly}} entitled “Women 2000: Gender Equality, Development and Peace for the Twenty-first Century” (A/S-23/10/Rev.1), in particular those concerning sexual violence and women in situations of armed conflict;

text: Reaffirming also the obligations of States Parties to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, the Optional Protocol thereto, the Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Optional Protocols thereto, and urging states that have not yet done so to consider ratifying or acceding to them,

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Ratification or accession to CEDAW and CRC and their Optional Protocols

textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* also the obligations of {{States Parties}} to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, the Optional Protocol thereto, the Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Optional Protocols thereto, and *urging* {{states}} that have not yet done so to consider [[ratifying or acceding]] to them,
uncertainties: This is a preambular paragraph; while it includes a directive-style participle ("urging"), assignees are not extracted for preambular text. Treating "ratifying or acceding" as a deliverable (legislation) may be borderline since it is aspirational in a preambular clause.

text: Noting that civilians account for the vast majority of those adversely affected by armed conflict; that women and girls are particularly targeted by the use of sexual violence, including as a tactic of war to humiliate, dominate, instil fear in, disperse and/or forcibly relocate civilian members of a community or ethnic group; and that sexual violence perpetrated in this manner may in some instances persist after the cessation of hostilities;
textWithHighlights: *Noting* that civilians account for the vast majority of those adversely affected by armed conflict; that women and girls are particularly targeted by the use of sexual violence, including as a tactic of war to humiliate, dominate, instil fear in, disperse and/or forcibly relocate civilian members of a community or ethnic group; and that sexual violence perpetrated in this manner may in some instances persist after the cessation of hostilities;

text: Recalling its condemnation in the strongest terms of all sexual and other forms of violence committed against civilians in armed conflict, in particular women and children;
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* its condemnation in the strongest terms of all sexual and other forms of violence committed against civilians in armed conflict, in particular women and children;

text: Reiterating deep concern that, despite its repeated condemnation of violence against women and children in situations of armed conflict, including sexual violence in situations of armed conflict, and despite its calls addressed to all parties to armed conflict for the cessation of such acts with immediate effect, such acts continue to occur, and in some situations have become systematic and widespread, reaching appalling levels of brutality,
textWithHighlights: *Reiterating deep concern* that, despite its repeated condemnation of violence against women and children in situations of armed conflict, including sexual violence in situations of armed conflict, and despite its calls addressed to all parties to armed conflict for the cessation of such acts with immediate effect, such acts continue to occur, and in some situations have become systematic and widespread, reaching appalling levels of brutality,

text: Recalling the inclusion of a range of sexual violence offences in the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court and the statutes of the ad hoc international criminal tribunals,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* the inclusion of a range of sexual violence offences in the Rome Statute of the {{International Criminal Court}} and the statutes of the {{ad hoc international criminal tribunals}},

text: Reaffirming the important role of women in the prevention and resolution of conflicts and in peacebuilding, and stressing the importance of their equal participation and full involvement in all efforts for the maintenance and promotion of peace and security, and the need to increase their role in decision-making with regard to conflict prevention and resolution,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* the important role of women in the prevention and resolution of conflicts and in peacebuilding, and *stressing* the importance of their equal participation and full involvement in all efforts for the maintenance and promotion of peace and security, and the need to increase their role in decision-making with regard to conflict prevention and resolution,

text: Deeply concerned also about the persistent obstacles and challenges to women’s participation and full involvement in the prevention and resolution of conflicts as a result of violence, intimidation and discrimination, which erode women’s capacity and legitimacy to participate in post-conflict public life, and acknowledging the negative impact this has on durable peace, security and reconciliation, including post-conflict peacebuilding,
textWithHighlights: *Deeply concerned* also about the persistent obstacles and challenges to women’s participation and full involvement in the prevention and resolution of conflicts as a result of violence, intimidation and discrimination, which erode women’s capacity and legitimacy to participate in post-conflict public life, and *acknowledging* the negative impact this has on durable peace, security and reconciliation, including post-conflict peacebuilding,

text: Recognizing that States bear primary responsibility to respect and ensure the human rights of their citizens, as well as all individuals within their territory as provided for by relevant international law,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that {{States}} bear primary responsibility to respect and ensure the human rights of their citizens, as well as all individuals within their territory as provided for by relevant international law,
uncertainties: "States" is interpreted as UN Member States; no operative tasks or deliverables are present since this is a preambular clause.

text: Reaffirming that parties to armed conflict bear the primary responsibility to take all feasible steps to ensure the protection of affected civilians,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* that parties to armed conflict bear the primary responsibility to take all feasible steps to ensure the protection of affected civilians,

text: Welcoming the ongoing coordination of efforts within the United Nations system, marked by the inter-agency initiative “United Nations Action against Sexual Violence in Conflict,” to create awareness about sexual violence in armed conflicts and post-conflict situations and, ultimately, to put an end to it,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: United Nations Action against Sexual Violence in Conflict
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: United Nations Action against Sexual Violence in Conflict

textWithHighlights: *Welcoming* the ongoing coordination of efforts within the {{United Nations system}}, marked by the inter-agency initiative “{{United Nations Action against Sexual Violence in Conflict}},” to create awareness about sexual violence in armed conflicts and post-conflict situations and, ultimately, to put an end to it,

text: Stresses that sexual violence, when used or commissioned as a tactic of war in order to deliberately target civilians or as a part of a widespread or systematic attack against civilian populations, can significantly exacerbate situations of armed conflict and may impede the restoration of international peace and security, affirms in this regard that effective steps to prevent and respond to such acts of sexual violence can significantly contribute to the maintenance of international peace and security, and expresses its readiness, when considering situations on the agenda of the Council, to, where necessary, adopt appropriate steps to address widespread or systematic sexual violence;
textWithHighlights: *Stresses* that sexual violence, when used or commissioned as a tactic of war in order to deliberately target civilians or as a part of a widespread or systematic attack against civilian populations, can significantly exacerbate situations of armed conflict and may impede the restoration of international peace and security, *affirms* in this regard that effective steps to prevent and respond to such acts of sexual violence can significantly contribute to the maintenance of international peace and security, and *expresses its readiness*, when considering situations on the agenda of the {{Council}}, to, where necessary, adopt appropriate steps to address widespread or systematic sexual violence;
uncertainties: "Affirms" is not in the provided verb list; normalized to "confirm" (observing). "Expresses its readiness" is normalized to "express" (evaluative) although it is not about concern specifically. No deliverable extracted for "adopt appropriate steps" as it is not concrete and is contingent.

text: Demands the immediate and complete cessation by all parties to armed conflict of all acts of sexual violence against civilians with immediate effect;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Cessation of sexual violence against civilians

textWithHighlights: *Demands* the immediate and complete [[cessation]] by <<all parties to armed conflict>> of all acts of sexual violence against civilians with immediate effect;
uncertainties: Deliverable type is approximated as 'policy' since the directive is to cease acts of sexual violence; no exact category fits perfectly.

text: Demands that all parties to armed conflict immediately take appropriate measures to protect civilians, including women and girls, from all forms of sexual violence, which could include, inter alia, enforcing appropriate military disciplinary measures and upholding the principle of command responsibility, training troops on the categorical prohibition of all forms of sexual violence against civilians, debunking myths that fuel sexual violence, vetting armed and security forces to take into account past actions of rape and other forms of sexual violence, and evacuation of women and children under imminent threat of sexual violence to safety; and requests the Secretary-General, where appropriate, to encourage dialogue to address this issue in the context of broader discussions of conflict resolution between appropriate UN officials and the parties to the conflict, taking into account, inter alia, the views expressed by women of affected local communities;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: enforce military disciplinary measures
uphold command responsibility
train troops on prohibition of sexual violence
debunk myths that fuel sexual violence
vet armed and security forces considering past sexual violence
evacuate women and children under imminent threat to safety
encourage dialogue on conflict resolution between UN officials and conflict parties

textWithHighlights: *Demands* that all <<parties to armed conflict>> immediately take appropriate measures to protect civilians, including women and girls, from all forms of sexual violence, which could include, inter alia, enforcing appropriate [[military disciplinary measures]] and upholding the principle of [[command responsibility]], [[training troops]] on the categorical prohibition of all forms of sexual violence against civilians, [[debunking myths]] that fuel sexual violence, [[vetting armed and security forces]] to take into account past actions of rape and other forms of sexual violence, and [[evacuation of women and children]] under imminent threat of sexual violence to safety; and *requests* the <<Secretary-General>>, where appropriate, to encourage [[dialogue]] to address this issue in the context of broader discussions of conflict resolution between appropriate UN officials and the {{parties to the conflict}}, taking into account, inter alia, the views expressed by women of affected local communities;
uncertainties:
- Assignee 'parties to armed conflict' includes non-state actors; classified as 'other' per schema.
- Deliverable type choices for disciplinary measures and vetting could alternatively be 'standards' rather than 'policy.
- 'Dialogue' categorized as 'meeting' although the task is to encourage rather than convene.
- 'UN officials' not mapped to a specific listed entity and thus not highlighted as a mention.

text: Notes that rape and other forms of sexual violence can constitute a war crime, a crime against humanity, or a constitutive act with respect to genocide, stresses the need for the exclusion of sexual violence crimes from amnesty provisions in the context of conflict resolution processes, and calls upon Member States to comply with their obligations for prosecuting persons responsible for such acts, to ensure that all victims of sexual violence, particularly women and girls, have equal protection under the law and equal access to justice, and stresses the importance of ending impunity for such acts as part of a comprehensive approach to seeking sustainable peace, justice, truth, and national reconciliation;
textWithHighlights: *Notes* that rape and other forms of sexual violence can constitute a war crime, a crime against humanity, or a constitutive act with respect to genocide, *stresses* the need for the exclusion of sexual violence crimes from amnesty provisions in the context of conflict resolution processes, and *calls upon* <<Member States>> to comply with their obligations for prosecuting persons responsible for such acts, to ensure that all victims of sexual violence, particularly women and girls, have equal protection under the law and equal access to justice, and *stresses* the importance of ending impunity for such acts as part of a comprehensive approach to seeking sustainable peace, justice, truth, and national reconciliation;
uncertainties: Considered extracting deliverables such as 'prosecuting persons responsible' and 'equal access to justice', but these do not map cleanly to the predefined deliverable types; therefore, no deliverables were recorded.

text: Affirms its intention, when establishing and renewing state-specific sanctions regimes, to take into consideration the appropriateness of targeted and graduated measures against parties to situations of armed conflict who commit rape and other forms of sexual violence against women and girls in situations of armed conflict;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Targeted and graduated sanctions measures against perpetrators of sexual violence

textWithHighlights: *Affirms* its intention, when establishing and renewing state-specific sanctions regimes, to take into consideration the appropriateness of [[targeted and graduated measures]] against parties to situations of armed conflict who commit rape and other forms of sexual violence against women and girls in situations of armed conflict;
uncertainties: The verb "Affirms" is not in the provided exhaustive list of operative verbs. It was normalized to "commit" (deciding) because the Council is affirming its intention to act in future. Alternatively, it could be treated as a reinforcing verb. The deliverable focuses on "targeted and graduated measures" as a policy commitment to consider such sanctions, which is somewhat abstract but represents the concrete policy intent of the paragraph.

text: Requests the Secretary-General, in consultation with the Security Council, the Special Committee on Peacekeeping Operations and its Working Group and relevant States, as appropriate, to develop and implement appropriate training programs for all peacekeeping and humanitarian personnel deployed by the United Nations in the context of missions as mandated by the Council to help them better prevent, recognize and respond to sexual violence and other forms of violence against civilians;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Training programs for UN peacekeeping and humanitarian personnel on preventing, recognizing and responding to sexual violence

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Special Committee on Peacekeeping Operations and its Working Group

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>>, in consultation with the {{Security Council}}, the {{Special Committee on Peacekeeping Operations and its Working Group}} and relevant States, as appropriate, to develop and implement appropriate [[training programs]] for all peacekeeping and humanitarian personnel deployed by the {{United Nations}} in the context of missions as mandated by the {{Council}} to help them better prevent, recognize and respond to sexual violence and other forms of violence against civilians;
uncertainties: The 'Special Committee on Peacekeeping Operations and its Working Group' is treated as 'Other (Other United Nations Bodies)' since it is not explicitly listed among predefined entities. The reference to 'Council' is interpreted as the Security Council.

text: Requests the Secretary-General to continue and strengthen efforts to implement the policy of zero tolerance of sexual exploitation and abuse in United Nations peacekeeping operations; and urges troop and police contributing countries to take appropriate preventative action, including pre-deployment and in-theater awareness training, and other action to ensure full accountability in cases of such conduct involving their personnel;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Implementation of zero-tolerance policy on sexual exploitation and abuse in UN peacekeeping
deliverables.deliverable: implement the policy of zero tolerance

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Awareness training (pre-deployment and in-theater)

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to continue and strengthen efforts to [[implement the policy of zero tolerance]] of sexual exploitation and abuse in {{United Nations}} peacekeeping operations; and *urges* <<troop and police contributing countries>> to take appropriate preventative action, including [[pre-deployment and in-theater awareness training]], and other action to ensure full accountability in cases of such conduct involving their personnel;
uncertainties: Normalized name for the group of assignees ('troop- and police-contributing countries') and the classification of 'implement the policy of zero tolerance' under 'policy' involve minor interpretation.

text: Encourages troop and police contributing countries, in consultation with the Secretary-General, to consider steps they could take to heighten awareness and the responsiveness of their personnel participating in UN peacekeeping operations to protect civilians, including women and children, and prevent sexual violence against women and girls in conflict and post-conflict situations, including wherever possible the deployment of a higher percentage of women peacekeepers or police;
textWithHighlights: *Encourages* <<troop and police contributing countries>>, in consultation with the {{Secretary-General}}, to consider steps they could take to heighten awareness and the responsiveness of their personnel participating in UN peacekeeping operations to protect civilians, including women and children, and prevent sexual violence against women and girls in conflict and post-conflict situations, including wherever possible the deployment of a higher percentage of women peacekeepers or police;
uncertainties: Considered whether to mark a deliverable for 'deployment of a higher percentage of women peacekeepers or police'; decided against it due to lack of a fitting deliverable category and the phrasing as an example within an encouragement to consider steps.

text: Requests the Secretary-General to develop effective guidelines and strategies to enhance the ability of relevant UN peacekeeping operations, consistent with their mandates, to protect civilians, including women and girls, from all forms of sexual violence and to systematically include in his written reports to the Council on conflict situations his observations concerning the protection of women and girls and recommendations in this regard;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Guidelines to enhance protection of civilians from sexual violence
Strategies to enhance protection of civilians from sexual violence
Written reports to the Security Council on conflict situations
Observations on protection of women and girls
Recommendations on protection of women and girls

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to develop effective [[guidelines]] and [[strategies]] to enhance the ability of relevant UN peacekeeping operations, consistent with their mandates, to protect civilians, including women and girls, from all forms of sexual violence and to systematically include in his [[written reports]] to the {{Council}} on conflict situations his [[observations]] concerning the protection of women and girls and [[recommendations]] in this regard;
uncertainties: Classifying “guidelines” as policy (vs. standards) is somewhat interpretive; they could also be seen as standards. The reports already exist; the directive is to include observations and recommendations in them.

text: Requests the Secretary-General and relevant United Nations agencies, inter alia, through consultation with women and women-led organizations as appropriate, to develop effective mechanisms for providing protection from violence, including in particular sexual violence, to women and girls in and around UN managed refugee and internally displaced persons camps, as well as in all disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration processes, and in justice and security sector reform efforts assisted by the United Nations;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: mechanisms to provide protection from violence for women and girls

textWithHighlights: *Requests* the <<Secretary-General>> and relevant <<United Nations agencies>>, inter alia, through consultation with women and women-led organizations as appropriate, to develop effective [[mechanisms]] for providing protection from violence, including in particular sexual violence, to women and girls in and around UN managed refugee and internally displaced persons camps, as well as in all disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration processes, and in justice and security sector reform efforts assisted by the {{United Nations}};
uncertainties: Classifying "mechanisms" as a policy deliverable; could also be interpreted as strategy or standards depending on implementation details.

text: Stresses the important role the Peacebuilding Commission can play by including in its advice and recommendations for post-conflict peacebuilding strategies, where appropriate, ways to address sexual violence committed during and in the aftermath of armed conflict, and in ensuring consultation and effective representation of women’s civil society in its country-specific configurations, as part of its wider approach to gender issues;
textWithHighlights: *Stresses* the important role the {{Peacebuilding Commission}} can play by including in its advice and recommendations for post-conflict peacebuilding strategies, where appropriate, ways to address sexual violence committed during and in the aftermath of armed conflict, and in ensuring consultation and effective representation of {{women’s civil society}} in its country-specific configurations, as part of its wider approach to gender issues;
uncertainties: Peacebuilding Commission is not listed among predefined entities; classified as a UN Organ and kept full name as normalized. No concrete deliverables or assignees are present, as the paragraph reinforces rather than directs actions.

text: Urges the Secretary-General and his Special Envoys to invite women to participate in discussions pertinent to the prevention and resolution of conflict, the maintenance of peace and security, and post-conflict peacebuilding, and encourages all parties to such talks to facilitate the equal and full participation of women at decision-making levels;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: invite women to participate in discussions
facilitate participation of women at decision-making levels
deliverables.deliverable: facilitate the equal and full participation of women

textWithHighlights: *Urges* the <<Secretary-General>> and his <<Special Envoys>> to [[invite women to participate]] in discussions pertinent to the prevention and resolution of conflict, the maintenance of peace and security, and post-conflict peacebuilding, and *encourages* <<all parties to such talks>> to [[facilitate the equal and full participation of women]] at decision-making levels;
uncertainties: "Special Envoys" is treated as a UN Secretariat assignee normalized as "UN Special Envoys" (not a standard list entity). "All parties to such talks" is broad; included as an assignee of type "other". Deliverable type "meeting" is used to capture participation in discussions; other classifications might also be arguable.

text: Urges all parties concerned, including Member States, United Nations entities and financial institutions, to support the development and strengthening of the capacities of national institutions, in particular of judicial and health systems, and of local civil society networks in order to provide sustainable assistance to victims of sexual violence in armed conflict and post-conflict situations;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: capacity building of national institutions and local civil society networks
deliverables.deliverable: development and strengthening of the capacities

textWithHighlights: *Urges* all parties concerned, including <<Member States>>, <<United Nations entities>> and <<financial institutions>>, to support the [[development and strengthening of the capacities]] of national institutions, in particular of judicial and health systems, and of local civil society networks in order to provide sustainable assistance to victims of sexual violence in armed conflict and post-conflict situations;
uncertainties: "United Nations entities" is broadly mapped to "UN System"; "financial institutions" is normalized to the standard category "international financial institutions" although the text does not specify "international".

text: Urges appropriate regional and sub-regional bodies in particular to consider developing and implementing policies, activities, and advocacy for the benefit of women and girls affected by sexual violence in armed conflict;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: policies for women and girls affected by sexual violence in conflict
advocacy for women and girls affected by sexual violence in conflict

textWithHighlights: *Urges* appropriate <<regional>> and <<sub-regional bodies>> in particular to consider developing and implementing [[policies]], activities, and [[advocacy]] for the benefit of women and girls affected by sexual violence in armed conflict;
uncertainties: The directive uses the phrasing “to consider developing and implementing,” which makes the outputs somewhat aspirational; ‘policies’ and ‘advocacy’ were extracted as the most concrete deliverables. “Activities” was deemed too vague to classify as a deliverable type. “Sub-regional organizations” is not in the provided entity list and was normalized as a custom ‘other’ entity.

text: Also requests the Secretary-General to submit a report to the Council by 30 June 2009 on the implementation of this resolution in the context of situations which are on the agenda of the Council, utilizing information from available United Nations sources, including country teams, peacekeeping operations, and other United Nations personnel, which would include, inter alia, information on situations of armed conflict in which sexual violence has been widely or systematically employed against civilians; analysis of the prevalence and trends of sexual violence in situations of armed conflict; proposals for strategies to minimize the susceptibility of women and girls to such violence; benchmarks for measuring progress in preventing and addressing sexual violence; appropriate input from United Nations implementing partners in the field; information on his plans for facilitating the collection of timely, objective, accurate, and reliable information on the use of sexual violence in situations of armed conflict, including through improved coordination of UN activities on the ground and at Headquarters; and information on actions taken by parties to armed conflict to implement their responsibilities as described in this resolution, in particular by immediately and completely ceasing all acts of sexual violence and in taking appropriate measures to protect women and girls from all forms of sexual violence;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Report on implementation of this resolution for situations on SC agenda
Information on conflicts with widespread or systematic sexual violence
deliverables.deliverable: information on situations of armed conflict

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Analysis of prevalence and trends of sexual violence in armed conflict
Recommendations for strategies to minimize susceptibility of women and girls
Benchmarks to measure progress in preventing and addressing sexual violence
Input from UN implementing partners in the field
Information on plans to facilitate collection of timely, objective, accurate and reliable data on sexual violence
Information on actions taken by parties to armed conflict to implement responsibilities

textWithHighlights: Also *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to submit a [[report]] to the {{Council}} by 30 June 2009 on the implementation of this resolution in the context of situations which are on the agenda of the Council, utilizing information from available {{United Nations sources}}, including {{country teams}}, peacekeeping operations, and other {{United Nations personnel}}, which would include, inter alia, [[information on situations of armed conflict]] in which sexual violence has been widely or systematically employed against civilians; [[analysis]] of the prevalence and trends of sexual violence in situations of armed conflict; [[proposals]] for strategies to minimize the susceptibility of women and girls to such violence; [[benchmarks]] for measuring progress in preventing and addressing sexual violence; appropriate [[input]] from {{United Nations implementing partners}} in the field; [[information on his plans]] for facilitating the collection of timely, objective, accurate, and reliable information on the use of sexual violence in situations of armed conflict, including through improved coordination of {{UN}} activities on the ground and at Headquarters; and [[information on actions taken]] by {{parties to armed conflict}} to implement their responsibilities as described in this resolution, in particular by immediately and completely ceasing all acts of sexual violence and in taking appropriate measures to protect women and girls from all forms of sexual violence;
uncertainties: Classifying “proposals for strategies” as recommendations (rather than strategies) and “benchmarks” as standards involves judgment. “United Nations implementing partners” was normalized to UN System; in practice this could include some non-UN partners, but the text specifies UN implementing partners.

text: Decides to remain actively seized of the matter.
textWithHighlights: *Decides* to remain actively seized of the matter.
